trans-unit.source: Get started with Azure App Service Mobile Apps for Xamarin.iOS apps | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Get started with Azure App Service Mobile Apps for Xamarin.iOS apps | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Follow this tutorial to get started with using Mobile Apps for Xamarin.iOS development.
trans-unit.target: Follow this tutorial to get started with using Mobile Apps for Xamarin.iOS development.

trans-unit.source: Create a Xamarin.iOS app
trans-unit.target: Create a Xamarin.iOS app

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to add a cloud-based backend service to a Xamarin.iOS mobile app by using an Azure mobile app backend.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to add a cloud-based backend service to a Xamarin.iOS mobile app by using an Azure mobile app backend.

trans-unit.source: You will create both a new mobile app backend and a simple _Todo list_ Xamarin.iOS app that stores app data in Azure.
trans-unit.target: You will create both a new mobile app backend and a simple _Todo list_ Xamarin.iOS app that stores app data in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Completing this tutorial is a prerequisite for all other Xamarin.iOS tutorials about using the Mobile Apps feature in Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: Completing this tutorial is a prerequisite for all other Xamarin.iOS tutorials about using the Mobile Apps feature in Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial, you need the following:
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial, you need the following:

trans-unit.source: An active Azure account.
trans-unit.target: An active Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an account, you can sign up for an Azure trial and get up to 10 free mobile apps that you can keep using even after your trial ends.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an account, you can sign up for an Azure trial and get up to 10 free mobile apps that you can keep using even after your trial ends.

trans-unit.source: For details, see [Azure Free Trial](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/).
trans-unit.target: For details, see [Azure Free Trial](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/).

trans-unit.source: [Visual Studio Community 2013] or later.
trans-unit.target: [Visual Studio Community 2013] or later.

trans-unit.source: If you install Visual Studio Community 2013, install [Xamarin] separately.
trans-unit.target: If you install Visual Studio Community 2013, install [Xamarin] separately.

trans-unit.source: You can install the Xamarin tools when you install Visual Studio 2015.
trans-unit.target: You can install the Xamarin tools when you install Visual Studio 2015.

trans-unit.source: A Mac with [Xcode] v7.0 or later and [Xamarin Studio] installed.
trans-unit.target: A Mac with [Xcode] v7.0 or later and [Xamarin Studio] installed.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE]If you plan to build your app on a Windows-based computer by using Visual Studio, you'll still need access to a networked Mac to do it.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE]If you plan to build your app on a Windows-based computer by using Visual Studio, you'll still need access to a networked Mac to do it.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you want to get started with Azure App Service before you sign up for an Azure account, go to [Try App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=523751&appServiceName=mobile).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you want to get started with Azure App Service before you sign up for an Azure account, go to [Try App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=523751&appServiceName=mobile).

trans-unit.source: There, you can immediately create a short-lived starter mobile app in App Service—no credit card required, and no commitments.
trans-unit.target: There, you can immediately create a short-lived starter mobile app in App Service—no credit card required, and no commitments.

trans-unit.source: Create a new Azure mobile app backend
trans-unit.target: Create a new Azure mobile app backend

trans-unit.source: Download the server project
trans-unit.target: Download the server project

trans-unit.source: On your PC, visit the [Azure portal].
trans-unit.target: On your PC, visit the [Azure portal].

trans-unit.source: Click **Browse All** > **Mobile Apps**, and then click the mobile app backend that you just created.
trans-unit.target: Click **Browse All** > **Mobile Apps**, and then click the mobile app backend that you just created.

trans-unit.source: In the Mobile App blade, click **Settings**, and then under **Mobile App**, click **Quickstart** > **Xamarin.iOS**.
trans-unit.target: In the Mobile App blade, click **Settings**, and then under **Mobile App**, click **Quickstart** > **Xamarin.iOS**.

trans-unit.source: Under **Download and run your server project**, click **Download**.
trans-unit.target: Under **Download and run your server project**, click **Download**.

trans-unit.source: Extract the compressed project files to your PC, and open the solution in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Extract the compressed project files to your PC, and open the solution in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Test your backend project locally
trans-unit.target: Test your backend project locally

trans-unit.source: Publish the server project to Azure
trans-unit.target: Publish the server project to Azure

trans-unit.source: Download and run the Xamarin.iOS app
trans-unit.target: Download and run the Xamarin.iOS app

trans-unit.source: On your Mac, open the [Azure portal] in a browser window.
trans-unit.target: On your Mac, open the [Azure portal] in a browser window.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] It's easier to run your Xamarin.iOS app on a Mac.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] It's easier to run your Xamarin.iOS app on a Mac.

trans-unit.source: You can run the Xamarin.iOS app by using Visual Studio on your Windows-based computer if you want, but it's a bit more complicated because you have to connect to a networked Mac.
trans-unit.target: You can run the Xamarin.iOS app by using Visual Studio on your Windows-based computer if you want, but it's a bit more complicated because you have to connect to a networked Mac.

trans-unit.source: If you're interested in doing that, see [Installing Xamarin.iOS on Windows].
trans-unit.target: If you're interested in doing that, see [Installing Xamarin.iOS on Windows].

trans-unit.source: Under **Download and run your Xamarin.iOS project**, click the **Download** button.
trans-unit.target: Under **Download and run your Xamarin.iOS project**, click the **Download** button.

trans-unit.source: This downloads a project that contains a client application that is connected to your mobile app.
trans-unit.target: This downloads a project that contains a client application that is connected to your mobile app.

trans-unit.source: Save the compressed project file to your local computer, and make a note of where you save it.
trans-unit.target: Save the compressed project file to your local computer, and make a note of where you save it.

trans-unit.source: Extract the project that you downloaded, and then open it in Xamarin Studio (or Visual Studio).
trans-unit.target: Extract the project that you downloaded, and then open it in Xamarin Studio (or Visual Studio).

trans-unit.source: Press the F5 key to build the project and start the app in the iPhone emulator.
trans-unit.target: Press the F5 key to build the project and start the app in the iPhone emulator.

trans-unit.source: In the app, type meaningful text, such as _Learn Xamarin_, and then click the **+** button.
trans-unit.target: In the app, type meaningful text, such as _Learn Xamarin_, and then click the **+** button.

trans-unit.source: This sends a POST request to the new mobile app backend hosted in Azure.
trans-unit.target: This sends a POST request to the new mobile app backend hosted in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Data from the request is inserted into the TodoItem table.
trans-unit.target: Data from the request is inserted into the TodoItem table.

trans-unit.source: Items stored in the table are returned by the mobile app backend, and the data is displayed in the list.
trans-unit.target: Items stored in the table are returned by the mobile app backend, and the data is displayed in the list.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE]You can review the code that accesses your mobile app backend to query and insert data in the QSTodoService.cs C# file.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE]You can review the code that accesses your mobile app backend to query and insert data in the QSTodoService.cs C# file.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.target: [Add authentication to your app ](app-service-mobile-dotnet-backend-xamarin-ios-get-started-users-preview.md)

trans-unit.source: Learn how to authenticate users of your app by using an identity provider.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to authenticate users of your app by using an identity provider.

trans-unit.source: [Add push notifications to your app](app-service-mobile-dotnet-backend-xamarin-ios-get-started-push-preview.md)
trans-unit.target: [Add push notifications to your app](app-service-mobile-dotnet-backend-xamarin-ios-get-started-push-preview.md)

trans-unit.source: Learn how to send a very basic push notification to your app.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to send a very basic push notification to your app.

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
